docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, said on Friday that ''it is impossible'' to have all Americans covered by health insurance, but he predicted that Congress would take incremental steps to expand coverage this year. Dr. Frist, a Tennessee Republican, said his state was ''going bankrupt'' as a result of trying to achieve universal insurance coverage.

headline.main: Frist Expects Congress to Try To Expand Health Coverage

docs.abstract: Sen majority leader Bill Frist says that 'it is impossible' to have all Americans covered by health insurance, but he predicts that Congress will take incremental steps to expand coverage in 2004; says his state, Tennessee, is 'going bankrupt' as result of trying to achieve universal insurance coverage; Frist is principal architect of law to provide prescription drug benefits to elderly; his photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued yesterday to oppose a tough new law on lead-paint hazards, which the City Council passed this week over his veto, saying that he hoped it would be thrown out in the courts. ''This is not the kind of bill we should have,'' Mayor Bloomberg said. ''Now there's a good chance the courts will throw it out because they threw out the last one based on not having an environmental impact statement. This one will probably be thrown out, I hope, for the same reason.''

headline.main: Mayor Still Opposing Law On Perils of Lead Paint

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg still opposes lead-paint hazards law that was passed by New York City Council over his veto; says he hopes court will throw it out based on lack of environmental impact statement (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina and Gen. Wesley K. Clark engaged in a war of words Friday over whether the senator had let down veterans, and Mr. Edwards's pollster said he faced an uphill battle in the primaries in Virginia and Tennessee next Tuesday. Mr. Edwards and General Clark are both banking heavily on these states, where, the Edwards campaign said, the two candidates are trailing Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts in the polls. Mr. Edwards has staked his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination on the claim that as a son of the South, he would defeat President Bush in the region, which has been pivotal in past Democratic victories.

headline.main: Clark Attacks Edwards Over Votes On Veterans

docs.abstract: Sen John Edwards and Gen Wesley K Clark are banking heavily on upcoming primaries in Virginia and Tennessee; Edwards campaign says both candidates are trailing Sen John Kerry in polls; Clark, campaigning in Nashville, criticizes Edwards for favoring trims in government spending on veterans health care (M)

byline.original: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD; Edward Wyatt contributed reporting from Cookeville, Tenn., for this article, and Jodi Wilgoren from Milwaukee

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Council voted in favor of offering health care benefits to the unmarried domestic partners of its city employees. The Council, which opened a citywide domestic partner registry last year and extended sick leave and funeral leave benefits to include domestic partnerships, estimates that the newly adopted proposal will cost about $250,000 annually. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Benefits For Unmarried Partners

docs.lead_paragraph: New Wage and Benefit Cuts Expected at US Airways Officials at US Airways, which is struggling to meet the conditions of federal loans that lifted it out of bankruptcy last year, began making the case for more wage and benefit cuts to skeptical union leaders who have already declared that ''the concessions stand is closed.'' US Airways has been working on a strategy since December, when its chief executive, David N. Siegel, said that increased competition from low-fare airlines was forcing it to revise the business plan it used when it emerged from bankruptcy last spring. [Page C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the battle between full-service and specialty hospitals referred incorrectly to government efforts to restrict the growth of specialty hospitals. While Medicare legislation passed last year effectively deferred plans for new specialty hospitals owned by doctors, it did not impose an 18-month moratorium on all new construction. In addition, while the Ohio House approved legislation on a statewide moratorium, the proposal was not enacted.
docs.abstract: Feb 3 article about battle between full-service and specialty hospitals referred incorrectly to government efforts to restrict growth of specialty hospitals; while Medicare legislation passed in 2003 effectively deferred plans for new specialty hospitals owned by doctors, it did not impose 18-month moratorium on new construction

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that in Washington, connections matter. So when Representative Billy Tauzin, one of the most influential Republicans on Capitol Hill, signaled that he would retire this year, it did not come as a surprise that some of the city's most powerful trade associations began a bidding war for his services. But now the courtship of Mr. Tauzin centers on a reported $2 million offer to head the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, the drug industry trade group that had billions at stake in the Medicare prescription drug legislation, which Mr. Tauzin helped shepherd on Capitol Hill.

headline.main: Washington Talk; Lawmaker's Plans to Lobby Raises Issue of Crossing Line

docs.abstract: Rep Billy Tauzin, who has signaled that he will retire in 2004, reportedly received $2 million offer to head Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, drug industry trade group that had billions at stake in Medicare prescription drug legislation, which Tauzin helped shepherd on Capitol Hill; Democrats, consumer groups and even some Republicans say Tauzin is crossing line; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it would cut about 9 percent of its work force, or 3,000 jobs, after the ranks of its health care policyholders fell sharply in the fourth quarter of last year. The announcement sent its shares tumbling. Cigna, struggling to recover after failing to price premiums in line with skyrocketing medical costs in recent years, posted a fourth-quarter net profit but also said it would cut its quarterly dividend sharply.

headline.main: Cigna Will Cut 3,000 Jobs; Drop in Policyholders Is Cited

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp says that it will cut about 9 percent of its work force, or 3,000 jobs, after ranks of its health care policyholders fall sharply in fourth quarter of 2003; posts fourth-quarter net profit of $290 million, but also says it will cut its quarterly dividend sharply; analysts say they are skeptical that company's proposed remedies will improve Cigna's problems in customer service, gauging medical costs and integrating technical systems (M)
docs.snippet: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it would cut about 9 percent of its work force, or 3,000 jobs, after the ranks of its health care policyholders fell sharply in the fourth quarter of last year. The announcement sent its shares tumbling.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Irwin Schiff, the nation's best-known promoter of claims that no law requires the payment of income taxes, suffers from delusions including a fantasy that he alone can properly interpret the tax laws, according to papers that he had his lawyers file in Federal District Court in Las Vegas. The filing, made on Jan. 23, is highly unusual, especially in a civil lawsuit. The document asks a judge to deny a summary judgment in favor of the Justice Department that Mr. Schiff owes $2.5 million in income taxes, fraud penalties and interest.

headline.main: Tax Protester Tells Federal Court That He Is Delusional

docs.abstract: Lawyers for Irwin Schiff, nation's best-known promoter of claims that no law requires payment of income taxes, file court papers saying he suffers from delusions, including a fantasy that he alone can properly interpret tax laws, and asking judge to deny summary judgment in favor of Justice Dept that Schiff owes $2.5 million in income taxes, fraud penalties and interest; Cindy Nuen, Schiff's girlfriend, sends e-mail to thousands of his supporters saying defense is ruse, only way Schiff can escape fraud penalties; federal appeals court is set to hear oral arguments on whether Schiff can be barred from selling his book The Fedreal Mafia: How the Federal Government Illegally Imposs and Unlawfully Collects Federal Income Taxes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Irwin Schiff, the nation's best-known promoter of claims that no law requires the payment of income taxes, suffers from delusions including a fantasy that he alone can properly interpret the tax laws, according to papers that he had his lawyers file...

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumer advocates are warning that millions of elderly Americans will face a bewildering array of new government-approved drug discount cards this spring, and Bush administration officials acknowledge that a major effort will be needed to clear up the confusion. Administration officials said yesterday that 106 health industry companies -- an unexpectedly large number -- met a deadline last week for applying to sponsor the new cards. The cards will be available to 10 million Medicare beneficiaries who do not have drug coverage, as a precursor to the prescription drug benefit scheduled to begin in 2006.

headline.main: Drug Discount for Elderly May Confuse as Well as Help

docs.abstract: Consumer advocates warn that millions of elderly Americans will face a bewildering array of new government-approved drug discount cards this spring, and Bush administration officials acknowledge that major effort will be needed to clear up confusion; administration officials say that 106 health industry companies--unexpectedly large number--met deadline last week for applying to sponsor new cards; cards will be available to 10 million Medicare beneficiaries who do not have drug coverage, as precursor to prescription drug benefit scheduled to begin in 2006; photos (L)
